questionList.questionText: A 65-year-old man is being evaluated for new-onset ptosis.  Earlier in the day, the patient underwent right total knee arthroplasty for advanced osteoarthritis with no operative complications.  While in the postoperative recovery unit, he had difficulty opening his left eye.  The patient has never experienced this, and his preoperative neurologic examination was unremarkable.  He has no history of double vision, difficulty swallowing, or limb weakness.  Medical history includes ischemic stroke with no residual deficits, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a 20-pack-year history.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 12/min.  Neurologic examination shows bilateral ptosis (left > right).  Pupils are equal in size and reactive to light.  An ice pack is placed over the closed eyelids for 2 minutes, leading to improvement of the ptosis.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Myasthenia gravis

Clinical
presentation

  • Fluctuating & fatigable proximal muscle weakness:
    • Ocular (eg, diplopia, ptosis)
    • Bulbar (eg, dysphagia, dysarthria)
    • Respiratory (myasthenic crisis)

Causes of
exacerbations

  • Medications: antibiotics (eg, fluoroquinolones, aminoglycosides), neuromuscular blocking agents, cardiac medications (eg, BBs), MgSO4, penicillamine
  • Physiologic stress: pregnancy/childbirth, surgery (especially thymectomy), infection

Diagnosis

  • Ice pack test (bedside), AChR-Ab (highly specific)
  • CT scan of chest (thymoma)

Treatment

  • AChE inhibitors (eg, pyridostigmine) ± immunotherapy (eg, corticosteroids, azathioprine)
  • Thymectomy

AChE = acetylcholinesterase; AChR-Ab = acetylcholine receptor antibodies; BBs = beta blockers; MgSO4 = magnesium sulfate.

This postoperative patient has bilateral, asymmetric ptosis that improves with the application of an ice pack.  This is strongly suspicious for myasthenia gravis (MG), a neuromuscular disorder caused by autoantibody-mediated blockade and degradation of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

The hallmark presentation of MG is a fluctuating, fatigable weakness that involves the eyes (most common), bulbar muscles, and/or extremities.  Weakness can be precipitated or exacerbated by various factors, including infections, pregnancy, surgery, and medications (eg, aminoglycosides, magnesium, beta blockers).  Nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents (eg, rocuronium), commonly administered during intubation for surgical procedures, can unmask MG symptoms because they are competitive antagonists of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

The diagnosis of MG can be supported with the bedside ice pack test, in which an ice pack is applied over the eyelids for several minutes, leading to an improvement in ptosis.  The cold temperature improves muscle strength by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby increasing acetylcholine availability to the nicotinic receptor.  Patients with positive test results should undergo confirmatory testing for MG with acetylcholine receptor antibodies (highly specific).

(Choice B)  Disruption of the oculosympathetic chain causes Horner syndrome, which is characterized by ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis.

(Choice C)  Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, a paraneoplastic disorder associated with small cell lung cancer, is caused by autoantibodies directed against presynaptic calcium channels in the neuromuscular junction, which leads to impaired acetylcholine release.  Although ocular manifestations (eg, diplopia, ptosis) may occur, they are a late manifestation of the disease (>1 year).  Patients typically have slowly progressive proximal muscle weakness and depressed deep tendon reflexes.  A positive ice pack test is classically associated with MG (but can rarely be positive in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome).

(Choice D)  Bell palsy is characterized by inflammation and edema of the facial nerve (CN VII), often due to herpes simplex activation, and typically presents with sudden-onset unilateral facial paralysis.

(Choice E)  Oculomotor nerve palsy may occur with microvascular nerve ischemia (eg, due to diabetes mellitus).  Although this could cause ptosis, patients would also have mydriasis and down-and-out deviation of the eye); an ice pack would not improve symptoms.

Educational objective:
Symptoms of myasthenia gravis can be precipitated by surgery and the use of neuromuscular blocking agents.  The diagnosis can be supported with a bedside test in which an ice pack is applied over the eyelids for several minutes.  This inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to an improvement in ptosis.

questionList.questionText: A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a shelter due to severe muscle pain and stiffness.  The manager of the shelter says that the patient has been restless and irritable since he arrived 2 days ago.  The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and injection drug use.  Temperature is 37.7 C (100 F), blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 102/min.  Both pupils are normal, equal, and reactive to light.  There are injection marks on the patient's arms and several abrasions and lacerations on his lower extremities.  He is unable to open his mouth completely.  Painful spasms of the neck muscles are triggered by physical touch of that area.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with muscle stiffness, trismus/lockjaw (inability to open his mouth completely), and painful muscle spasms triggered by physical touch likely has tetanus.  The disease develops when Clostridium tetani, which is normally found in soil, enters the body through a break in the skin (eg, puncture wound, lower extremity abrasion/laceration).  C tetani replicates in anaerobic conditions and secretes a toxin that binds to the peripheral nerve terminals.  Using retrograde axonal transport, the toxin migrates to interneurons in the CNS, where it blocks the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (glycine, GABA).

Manifestations typically begin within 7-10 days and include painful tonic contractions of the skeletal muscles with intermittent severe muscle spasms.  The first symptom is often trismus (lockjaw), but stiff neck, opisthotonos, and risus sardonicus are frequently seen.  In many cases, spasms are triggered by sensory stimuli such as physical touch.  Autonomic overactivity can cause sweating, labile blood pressure, and tachycardia.

Tetanus occurs almost exclusively in persons with poor access to health care because they are more likely to be unvaccinated or inadequately immunized.  For those who become ill, the infected wound should be debrided, and antibiotics should be started; human tetanus immune globulin (to bind residual circulating toxin) and tetanus toxoid should be administered.

(Choice A)  Botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum toxin, which leads to impairment of presynaptic acetylcholine release.  It usually presents with symmetric descending flaccid paralysis, blurred vision, and areflexia and can include diaphragmatic paralysis.

(Choice B)  Meningitis is a CNS infection due to microbial invasion that can cause confusion and stiff neck, but it is unlikely to cause painful muscle spasms.  Similarly, rabies can cause confusion and spasms, although hydrophobia and aerophobia (thought to be due to pharyngeal spasms) are classic.  Trismus is not usually seen in either of these conditions.

(Choice C)  Opiate withdrawal can present with tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, restlessness, and irritability.  Trismus and muscle spasms are unlikely.

(Choice D)  Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy mediated by cytotoxic T lymphocytes.  It usually presents with gradual proximal muscle weakness without prominent pain, muscle spasms, or trismus.

Educational objective:
Tetanus is a presynaptic neuromuscular junction disorder caused by the Clostridium tetani toxin, which blocks the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and GABA across the synaptic cleft, leading to painful muscle spasms and trismus (lockjaw).  It is seen almost exclusively in patients who are unvaccinated or incompletely immunized.
